comment.author: 44753927@N00
66853325@N00
comment._content: CmdrFire I know Hassies were used for Apollo 11, but this shot is from mission 15. At some point, NASA switched to Nikon, but I think it was still Hasselblad in 1971. Not totally sure though. UPDATE: Apollo 15 used several types of camera, but the Nikon was mounted on the module for night shots of the milky way, whereas the Hassy was hand-held on the surface: www.lpi.usra.edu/lunar/missions/apollo/apollo_15/photogra... "While on the surface, the crew took 1151 photographs with the Hasselblad cameras."

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: P.S. I just read that Irwin was effectively having a heart attack when this image was captured. He was working a 23-hour shift in a stressful situation. Fortunately, he could go back to the 100% oxygen and zero-g "intensive care unit" for returning home, but he had another heart attack a few months after returning to earth. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Irwin

comment.author: 66681399@N05
comment._content: This picture is really quite an amazing feat of camera work if you consider that it was taken without any means of knowing if everything was in shot. No viewfinder, no one to tell you if everything is in shot. Isn't it strange that the only thing visible on the dark part of the Lunar Lander is the American Flag? You cant put that down to two light sources. More likely a NASA artist and an airbrush! This picture was later used on postcards and NASA advertising.

comment.author: 43319077@N00
comment._content:
The surface of the Moon is like a super grey card. If fills in the shadows like a reflector. The shadows on the ground are dark because there is no bright sky to lighten them up. Anything that is standing up gets fill light from the ground.
They folded the rover like an origami project and stored it in the flat side of the bottom half of the LEM. They pulled a wire and out it popped and they had to lock all the joints. If you ever wondered how they got TV pictures of Neil Armstrong coming down the ladder for that giant step. They pulled a release lever in the lunar lander and a panel on the outside opened. It had a pre-aimed, focused black and white camera looking at the ladder. I remember there was a rather long empty shot of that ladder as we waited for Armstrong to squeeze through that small square hatch. I was ten years old when Apollo 11 landed on the Moon, but I still remember the details.
